original_title: Sri Lanka import expenditure drops, remittances, tourism earnings improve in Feb 2023
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s import expenditure recorded a notable decline compared to reduction in export earnings in February (year-on-year) while workers’ remittances and earnings from tourism continued to improve, the Central Bank said.
Gross official reserves strengthened further by end February 2023, compared to recent months, the central bank said in its external sector performance report for the month.
“The exchange rate appreciated notably in March 2023 following the greater flexibility that was allowed in the determination of the exchange rate,” the bank said.
Meanwhile, the Colombo Stock Exchange (CSE) and foreign investment in the government securities market recorded net inflows during February 2023.

In terms of overall exports, the bank said, despite recording a marginal growth compared to January 2023, earnings from merchandise exports declined by 10.2 percent in February 2023, year-on-year, to 982 million US dollars
With regard to imports, expenditure on merchandise imports was almost halved in February 2023 at1,021 million dollars, compared to February 2022, recording the lowest imports since May 2020..

“Registering over 400 million US dollar level for the second consecutive month this year, workers’ remittances recorded at 407 million US dollars during February 2023, in comparison to 205 million dollars in February 2022. Meanwhile, total departures for foreign employment were recorded at 23,974 during the month of February 2023. Total departures of foreign employment comprised unskilled (7,662), domestic aid (6,939) and skilled (6,582) categories,” the report said.

According to the report, tourist arrivals increased in February 2023 to 107,639, compared to 102,545 arrivals recorded in January 2023 and 96,507 recorded in February 2022. Russia, India, the United Kingdom, Germany, and France remained the main source countries for tourist arrivals in February 2023.

“Foreign investment in the government securities market recorded a notable net inflow in February 2023, while cumulative net inflow during January-February 2023 amounted to US dollars 30 million. Meanwhile, foreign inflows to the Colombo Stock Exchange (CSE), including both primary and secondary market transactions, recorded a net inflow of US dollars 8 million during February 2023 and US dollars 9 million during the two months ending February 2023,” it said.

Gross official reserves stood at 2.2 billion US dllars as at end February 2023. This included the swap facility from the People’s Bank of China, equivalent to around 1.4 billion dollars, which is subject to conditionalities on usability. The Central Bank recorded a net absorption of foreign exchange from the market in February 2023, resulting in a marginal improvement in liquid reserves by end February 2023.

Meanwhile, the first tranche of the Extended Fund Facility (EFF) from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) was received in March 2023 amounting to SDR 254 million (about US dollars 333 million), the report noted.

Sri Lanka’s exchange rate continued to remain stable through February 2023, before notably appreciating during March 2023 with the removal of the guidance band and mandatory sales requirement amidst improved market sentiments, the central bank said. (Colombo/Mar31/2023)
